channel.description: Recent content in Math Wiki on Ben Clingenpeel

item.title: Bell Numbers
item.description: Definition The \(n\)th Bell number, denoted \(B_n\) is the total number of ways of partitioning the set \([n]\). Properties The Bell numbers are given by the formula \[B_n = \sum_{k=0}^n \stirlingII{n}{k}\] where \(\stirlingII{n}{k}\) is the Stirling number of the second kind which counts the number of ways to partition \([n]\) into \(k\) nonempty parts. Theorem: For \(n \geq 1\), the bell numbers satisfy the recursion \[B_n = \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \binom{n-1}{k} B_k.\]

item.title: Cosets of a Subgroup
item.description: Definitions Let \((G, \cdot)\) be a group with a subgroup \(H\). We say that elements \(a, b \in G\) are left-equivalent, written \(a \sim_L b\), if and only if \(a\inv b \in H\). Similarly, we say they are right-equivalent, written \(a \sim_R b\), if and only if \(ab\inv \in H\). Then \(\sim_L\) and \(\sim_R\) are relations on \(G\), and we have that \(a\inv a = e \in H < G\), meaning \(a \sim_L a\) for all \(a \in G\), \(a \sim_L b\) means \(a\inv b \in H \implies b\inv a = (a\inv b)\inv \in H < G \implies b \sim_L a\) for all \(a,b \in G\), and \(a \sim_L b\) and \(b \sim_L c\) means \(a\inv c = (a\inv b) (b \inv c) \in H < G \implies a \sim_L c\) for all \(a,b,c \in G\), which means \(\sim_L\) is an equivalence relation on \(G\).

item.title: Equivalence Relations
item.description: Definitions A relation \(R\) on a set \(S\) is called an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. When \((a,b) \in R\), we write \(a \sim b\). The equivalence class of an element \(a \in S\) with equivalence relation \(R\) is the set \([a] := \{b \in S \mid a \sim b\}\) of elements equivalent to \(a\). Properties The equivalence classes of a relation \(R\) partition the set \(S\).

item.title: Functions
item.description: Also called maps. Definitions A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C}\) is a set of ordered pairs \((a,b)\) where \(a \in \mathcal{D}\) and \(b \in \mathcal{C}\) with the property that if \((a,b) \in f\) and \((a,c) \in f\), then \(b=c\). If \((a,b) \in f\), we write \(f(a)=b\). We call the set \(\mathcal{D}\) the domain of \(f\) and the set \(\mathcal{C}\) the codomain of \(f\). We call the set \(\{f(x) \mid x \in \mathcal{D}\}\) the image of \(f\), denoted \(\im (f)\).

item.title: Group Isomorphism Theorems
item.description: The First Isomorphism Theorem Let \(G\) and \(H\) be groups and let \(\varphi: G \to H\) be a homomorphism with kernel \(K\). Let \(\pi: G \to G/K\) be the canonical homomorphism from the group \(G\) to the quotient group \(G/K\). Then there is a unique isomorphism \(\tilde\varphi: G/K \to \im(G)\) such that \(\varphi = \tilde\varphi \circ \pi\). We have the following diagram: Corollary: If \(\varphi\) is surjective, then \(G/K \cong H\).

item.title: Integer Partitions
item.description: Definition An integer partition of the number \(n\) into \(k\) parts is a writing of \(n\) as a sum of \(k\) positive integers \(n = a_1 + a_2 + \dots + a_k\) where \(a_1 \geq a_2 \geq \dots \geq a_k \geq 1\). Properties The number of ways to partition the number \(n\) into \(k\) positive parts is given by the stirling number of the first kind, \(\stirlingI{n}{k}\). The total number of ways to partition the number \(n\) is given by \[p(n) := \sum_{k=1}^n \stirlingI{n}{k}.

item.title: Noncrossing Partitions
item.description: Definition Noncrossing partitions of \([n]\) are partitions of \([n]\) into parts \(\{B_1, \dots, B_k\}\) such that if \(a < b < c < d\) are elements of \([n]\) with \(a,c \in B_i\) and \(b,d \in B_j\), then \(i = j\). Otherwise, a partition is crossing. Properties Noncrossing partitions of \([n]\) can be visually represented as a series of \(n\) labeled dots with partitions represented by arcs connecting the dots that belong to a given part.

item.title: Permutation Matrices
item.description: Definition A permutation matrix of size \(n\) is a \(0/1\) matrix with entries all \(0\) except for a single \(1\) in each row and each column. Given a permutation \(\sigma\) on \([n]\), its associated permutation matrix \(A_\sigma\) is a \(0/1\) matrix in which the \(j\)th column is all \(0\) aside from a single \(1\) in the \(\sigma(j)\)th row. Properties The set of all permutation matrices of size \(n\) forms a group isomorphic to \(S_n\), the symmetric group on \(n\) symbols.

item.title: Permutations
item.description: Definitions A permutation on a set \(X\) is a bijection \(\sigma: X \to X\). The set of all permutations on the set \([n]\) is a group under composition and is called the symmetric group on \(n\) symbols. A fixed point of a permutation \(\sigma\) is an element \(i \in X\) such that \(\sigma(i) = i\). Cycle Notation A permutation \(\sigma\) can be written uniquely (up to cyclic shifts and reorderings) as the product of disjoint cycles.

item.title: Quotient Groups
item.description: Also called factor groups. Definition Let \((G, \cdot)\) be a group with normal subgroup \(N\). Then its corresponding quotient group, denoted \(G/N\), is the set of all left cosets of \(G\) (though \(N \triangleleft G\) means these are the same as the right cosets) together with group operation \(\cdot: G/N \times G/N\) given as follows. If \(aN, bN \in G/N\), then \(aN \cdot bN = (ab) N\). Properties The quotient group is a group.

item.title: Set Partitions
item.description: Definition A partition on a set \(X\) is a set \(\mathcal{P}\) of disjoint subsets of \(X\) such that \(X = \bigsqcup_{P \in \mathcal{P}} P\) where the sets \(P \in \mathcal{P}\) are called the parts of \(\mathcal{P}\). Properties The number of ways to partition a set of size \(n\) into exactly \(k\) nonempty parts is given by the stirling number of the second kind, \(\stirlingII{n}{k}\). The total number of ways to partition a set of size \(n\) is the \(n\)th Bell number.

item.title: Simple Groups
item.description: Building blocks. Definition A group \((G, \cdot)\) is simple if and only if it has no nontrivial proper normal subgroups. Properties If \(G\) is a simple group that is not abelian, then \(G\) is not solvable. Examples The only abelian simple groups are the cyclic groups of prime order, isomorphic to \(\Z_p\) for a prime \(p\). The alternating group \(A_n\) is simple for \(n \geq 5\).

item.title: Solvable Groups
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: Stirling Numbers
item.description: Definitions The Stirling numbers of the first kind, denoted \(\stirlingI{n}{k}\), count the number of ways integers \(n\) can be partitioned into \(k\) pieces, each of which is greater than or equal to one. The Stirling numbers of the second kind, denoted \(\stirlingII{n}{k}\), count the number of ways sets \([n]\) can be partitioned into \(k\) nonempty parts. Properties The Stirling numbers of the first kind satisfy the following recursion: \[\stirlingI{n}{k} = \stirlingI{n-k}{k} + \stirlingI{n-1}{k-1},\] and we also have the following: \[\begin{align*} &\stirlingI{n}{n} = 1 \\ &\stirlingI{n}{0} = 0 \quad n \geq 1 \\ &\stirlingI{n}{k} = 0 \quad k > n \\ &\stirlingI{n}{n-1} = 1 \\ &\stirlingI{n}{1} = 1 \\ &\stirlingI{n}{n-2} = 2 \\ &\stirlingI{n}{2} = \bigg \lfloor \frac{n}{2} \bigg \rfloor.

item.title: The Dihedral Group
item.description: Symmetries of a polygon. Definition The dihedral group \(D_n\) is the group of symmetries of a regular \(n\)-gon. The elements of the group are the rigid motions that act on the \(n\)-gon with barycenter at the origin, together with composition as the group operation. Properties The group contains \(n\) rotations (counting the identity as a rotation by \(0\) radians), written as \(r^j\) for \(0 \leq j < n\) and \(n\) reflections, all of which have order \(2\) and can be written as \(sr^j\) for a given reflection \(s\).

item.title: Abelian Groups
item.description: Groups that commute. Definition A group \((G, \cdot)\) is abelian if the group operation is commutative. That is, if \(a \cdot b = b \cdot a\) for all \(a,b \in G\). Properties In an abelian group, we have that \((ab)^n = a^n b^n\) for all \(a,b \in G\) and \(n \in \Z\). If \(G\) is abelian, then its center is the entire group \(G\), and every subgroup is normal. If the quotient group \(G/Z(G)\) is cyclic, then \(G\) is abelian.

item.title: Centralizers
item.description: Definitions Let \((G, \cdot)\) be a group with a subgroup \(H\). The centralizer of the subgroup \(H\) in \(G\), denoted \(C(H)\), is the set of elements of \(G\) that commute with all elements of \(H\). That is, \(C(H) = \{g \in G \mid gh = hg \,\, \forall h \in H\}\). For an element \(x \in G\), the centralizer of the element \(x\) in \(G\), denoted \(C(x)\) is the set of elements of \(G\) that commute with the element \(x\).

item.title: Group Automorphisms
item.description: Definition An automorphism of a group \((G, \cdot)\) is a map \(f: G \to G\) that is an ismorphism. An inner automorphism of \(G\) is an automorphism \(i_g: G \to G\) given by conjugation: \(i_g (x) = gxg\inv\). Properties Because automorphisms are bijections from the set \(G\) to itself, the set of all automorphisms, denoted \(\Aut (G)\), is a subset of \(\Sym(G)\), the symmetric group on \(G\). In fact, \(\Aut(G)\) is a subgroup of \(\Sym(G)\).

item.title: Group Homomorphisms
item.description: Definitions Let \((G, \cdot)\) and \((H, \circ)\) be groups. A map \(\varphi: G \to H\) is called a group homomorphism if it preserves the group operation. That is, \(\varphi\) is a homomorphism if and only if for all \(a,b \in G\) we have \(\varphi(a \cdot b) = \varphi(a) \circ \varphi(b)\). If a homomorphism \(\varphi\) is called a monomorphism if it is injective, an epimorphism if it is surjective, and an isomorphism if it is bijective.

item.title: Internal Direct Products
item.description: Definition Let \(G\) be a group with subgroups \(H\) and \(K\). We say that \(G\) is the internal direct product of \(H\) and \(K\) if and only if the follow three conditions hold: \(H\) and \(K\) are normal in \(G\) (\(H, K \triangleleft G\)), \(H\) and \(K\) intersect trivially (\(H \cap K = \{e\}\)), \(G\) is the set \(HK = \{hk \mid h \in H, k \in K\}\). Properties Lemma: If \(H,K \triangleleft G\) and \(H \cap K = \{e\}\), then for all \(h \in H\) and \(k \in K\), \(hk = kh\), that is, elements in \(H\) commute with elements in \(K\).

item.title: Lagrange's Theorem
item.description: Statement Let \((G, \cdot)\) be a finite group and let \(H\) be a subgroup of \(G\). Then \(\vert G \vert = [G:H] \vert H \vert\), and therefore the order of \(H\) divides the order of \(G\). Proof Since the cosets of \(H\) in \(G\) partition \(G\) into \([G:H]\) disjoint subsets, all of which have the same size, we have that \[G = \bigsqcup_{\text{distinct cosets } H_i} H_i \implies \vert G \vert = \sum_{\text{distinct cosets } H_i} \vert H_i \vert = [G:H] \vert H \vert.

item.title: Normal Subgroups
item.description: Definition A subgroup \(H\) of a group \((G,\cdot)\) is said to be normal, written \(H \triangleleft G\), if and only if its left and right cosets are equal. That is, if and only if \(gH = Hg\) for all \(g \in G\). Properties Proposition: The following are equivalent. \(H \triangleleft G\); \(gH = Hg\) for all \(g \in G\); \(gHg\inv = H\) for all \(g \in G\); \(gHg\inv \subset H\) for all \(g \in G\).

item.title: Subgroups
item.description: Definition A subgroup of a group \((G,\cdot)\) is a subset \(H \subset G\) such that \((H, \cdot)\) is a group under the same operation as \(G\). We write \(H < G\) if \(H\) is a subgroup of \(G\). Properties The sets \(\{e\}\) and \(G\) are subgroups of \(G\) for all groups \(G\). Subgroups that are not \(\{e\}\) are called nontrivial, and subgroups that are not \(G\) are called proper subgroups.

item.title: The Alternating Group
item.description: Definition The alternating group, denoted \(A_n\), is the normal subgroup of \(S_n\) containing all even permutations. Properties The group has order \(n! / 2\). It is not abelian or cyclic for \(n \geq 4\), and it is simple for \(n \geq 5\). Because \([S_n:A_n] = 2\), \(A_n\) is normal in \(S_n\). Examples The group \(A_4\) has order \(12\) but has no subgroups of order \(6\). This is because if \(H\) is a subgroup of order \(6\), it contains at least two \(3\)-cycles because \(A_4\) contains all eight \(3\)-cycles (since all odd-length cycles are even).

item.title: The Symmetric Group
item.description: Definitions The symmetric group on a set \(X\) is the group of bijections \[\Sym(X) = \{f: X \to X \mid f \text{ is bijective}\}\] together with the group operation of composition of mappings. The symmetric group on \(n\) symbols, denoted \(S_n\), is the symmetric group on the set \([n] := \{1, \dots, n\}\), the group of permutations. Properties The group \(S_n\) is not cyclic or abelian for \(n \geq 3\).

item.title: Cyclic Groups
item.description: Definitions A group \((G, \cdot)\) is a cyclic group if there exists an element \(a \in G\) such that every element of \(G\) can be written as \(a^k\) for some \(k \in \Z\). In this case, we write \(G = \langle a \rangle := \{a^k \mid k \in \Z \}\). Properties All cyclic groups are abelian. If \(G\) is an infinite cyclic group, then it is isomorphic to the integers, \((\Z, +)\), and if it is a finite cyclic group, then it is isomorphic to \(\Z_n\), the group of equivalence classes mod \(n\) where \(n = \vert G \vert\) is the order of the group.

item.title: External Direct Products
item.description: Definitions Let \((G, \cdot)\) and \((H, \circ)\) be groups. The external direct product of \(G\) and \(H\), is the set \(G \times H\), the cartesian product of \(G\) and \(H\) as sets, together with a group operation given by performing the group operations of \(G\) and \(H\) component-wise. That is, \((g_1,h_1) (g_2,h_2) = (g_1 \cdot g_2, h_1 \circ h_2)\) for elements \(g_1,g_2 \in G\) and \(h_1, h_2 \in H\). For an arbitrary collection of groups \(\{(G_\alpha, \circ_\alpha)\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\), the external direct product is defined analogously as the set \(G = \prod_{\alpha \in \lambda} G_\alpha\) together with the group operation \(\circ\) defined so that if \(x,y \in G\), then the projections satisfy \(\pi_\beta (x \circ y) = \pi_\beta(x) \circ_\beta \pi_\beta(y)\) for all \(\beta \in \lambda\).

item.title: Least Common Multiples
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: The Center of a Group
item.description: Definition Let \((G, \cdot)\) be a group. The center of \(G\) is the set \(\{x \in G \mid gx = xg \,\, \forall g \in G\}\), denoted \(Z(G)\), of elements in \(G\) that commute with all other elements. Properties If \(G\) is an abelian group, then \(Z(G) = G\). The center of \(G\) is always a normal subgroup of \(G\). Examples The center of \(D_n\) is trivial if \(n\) is odd, and equal to \(\{e,r^{n/2}\}\) if \(n\) is even.

item.title: Group Presentations

item.title: Groups
item.description: The symmetries of something. Definitions A group \((G, \cdot)\) is a set \(G\) together with a binary operation \(\cdot: G \times G \to G\) such that The group operation is associative: \((ab)c = a(bc)\) for all \(a,b,c \in G\); \(G\) has an identity element: there exists \(e \in G\) such that \(ae = a = ea\) for all \(a \in G\); Every element is invertible: for all \(a \in G\), there exists a \(b \in G\) such that \(ab = e = ba\).

item.title: Order of an Element in a Group
item.description: Definition Let \((G, \cdot)\) be a group and let \(g \in G\). The order of \(g\), denoted \(\vert g \vert\) is the smallest positive integer \(n\) such that \(g^n = e\), the identity element of \(G\). If such an \(n\) exists, \(g\) has finite order. Otherwise, \(g\) has infinite order. Properties By Lagrange’s Theorem, the order of \(g\) always divides the order of the group, \(\vert G \vert\). If \(g^m = e\), then the order of \(g\) divides \(m\).

item.title: Range
item.description: Also known as the image… Definition Let \(T \in \Lin(V,W)\) be a linear map between vector spaces \(V\) and \(W\). The range of \(T\), denoted \(\range T\), is the subset of \(W\) containing vectors of the form \(Tv\) for some \(v \in V\), that is, \[\range T = \{Tv \mid v \in V\}.\] Properties (3.19) Proposition: If \(T \in \Lin(V,W)\), then \(\range T\) is a subspace of \(W\). (3.22) Fundamental Theorem of Linear Maps: If \(V\) is a finite-dimensional vector space and \(T \in \Lin(V,W)\) is a linear map, then \[\dim V = \dim \, \nl T + \dim \, \range T,\] where \(\nl T\) denotes the null space of \(T\) and \(\dim V\) is the dimension of the space \(V\).

item.title: The General Linear Group
item.description: Definition The general linear group, denoted \(GL_n(\F)\), is the group of \(n\)-by-\(n\) invertible matrices over the field \(\F\).

item.title: The Group of Integers
item.description: Definition The set of equivalence classes on \(\Z\) modulo \(n\) forms a finite group. Properties The group is cyclic generated by the equivalence classes of numbers relatively prime to \(n\), and abelian since addition of equivalence classes is commutative.

item.title: The Group of Units
item.description: Sometimes denoted \(\Z_n^\times\). Definition The group of units mod \(n\), denoted \(U(n)\), is a finite group formed by removing the non-invertible elements of \(\Z_n\) (which are equivalence classes) under multiplication. Properties The group of units is an abelian group since multiplcation of equivalence classes is commutative. The group of units mod \(n\) is not always cyclic in general, but if \(n\) is \(2\), \(4\), \(p^k\), or \(2p^k\) for a prime \(p\) and natural number \(k\), then it is cyclic becuase the group has a generator.

item.title: The Klein Four-group
item.description: Definition The Klein four-group is a group that can be thought of in many ways, one of which is as the external direct product \(\Z_2 \times \Z_2\), and is typically denoted by \(V\). Properties The group is abelian. Every non-identity element has order \(2\). Examples The group can also be thought of as being given by the group presentation \(\langle a,b \mid a^2, b^2, (ab)^2 \rangle\). Alternatively, the group can be thought of as the subgroup of the general linear group \(GL_2(\R)\) given by \[V = \left\{ \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \right\}.

item.title: The Special Linear Group
item.description: Definition The special linear group denoted \(SL_n(\F)\) is the group of \(n\)-by-\(n\) invertible matrices over the field \(\F\) with determinant \(1\). Properties The special linear group \(SL_n(\F)\) is a normal subgroup of the general linear group \(GL_n(\F)\).

item.title: Vector spaces
item.description: Definitions A vector space over a field \(\F\) (here either \(\R\) or \(\C\)) is a set \(V\), together with addition (\(+\)) and scalar multiplication (\(\cdot\)) operations such that the following properties hold: commutativity: \(u + v = v + u\) for all \(u, v \in V\); associativity: \((u + v) + w = u + (v + w)\) and \((ab)v = a(bv)\) for all \(u,v,w \in V\), \(a,b \in \F\); additive identity: there exists an element \(0 \in V\) such that \(v + 0 = v\) for all \(v \in V\); additive inverse: for every \(v \in V\), there exists an element \(w \in V\) such that \(v + w = 0\); multiplicative identity: \(1v = v\) for all \(v \in V\); distributive properties: \(a(u + v) = au + av\) and \((a + b)v = av + bv\) for all \(v,w \in V\) and \(a,b \in \F\).

item.title: The Group of Integers
item.description: Definition The set of integers, \(\Z\), together with the operation addition forms an infinite group. Properties The group is cyclic generated by \(\pm 1\), and abelian since addition is commutative. Every subgroup of \(\Z\) has the form \(n\Z = \langle n \rangle = \{nz \mid z \in \Z\}\) for some \(n \in \Z\).

item.title: Coprime numbers
item.description: Definition Two numbers \(a,b \in \N\) are said to be coprime or relatively prime if their greatest common divisor is 1. Properties Because the gcd of two numbers \(a\) and \(b\) can always be written as an integral linear combination of \(a\) and \(b\), there always exist \(s,t \in \Z\) such that \(as + bt = 1\) if and only if \(a\) and \(b\) are coprime.

item.title: Euler's Totient Function
item.description: Definitions Euler’s totient function is a function \(\phi: \N \to \N\) such that \(\phi(n)\) is the number of numbers that are less than or equal to \(n\) and relatively prime to \(n\). That is, \[\phi(n) = \# \{m \in \N \mid m \leq n \text{ and } \gcd(m,n) = 1\}.\] Properties If \(p\) is a prime number, then \(\phi(p) = p-1\) because every natural number less than or equal to \(p\) is relatively prime to it except \(p\) itself.

item.title: Matrices
item.description: Definition A matrix is a rectangular array with \(m\) rows and \(n\) columns for positive integers \(m\) and \(n\). \[\begin{bmatrix} a_{1,1} & \dots & a_{1,n} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ a_{m,1} & \dots & a_{m,n} \end{bmatrix}\] A generic matrix looks like the above, where \(a_{i,j}\) are usually elements of \(\F\), either the reals or the complex numbers. For a matrix \(A\), we denote the entry in the \(i\)th row and \(j\)th column by \(A_{i,j}\).

item.title: Prime Numbers
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: Relations
item.description: Definitions A relation on a set \(S\) is a subset \(R \subset S \times S\). Two elements \(a,b \in S\) are related if and only if \((a,b) \in R\), and this is sometimes written \(aRb\). Relations are called reflexive if \((a,a) \in R\) for all \(a \in S\) (\(a\) is related to itself); irreflexive if \((a,a) \notin R\) for all \(a \in S\); symmetric if \((a,b) \in R\) implies \((b,a) \in R\); asymmetric if \((a,b) \in R\) implies \((b,a) \notin R\); antisymmetric if \((a,b),(b,a) \in R\) implies that \(a = b\); transitive if \((a,b),(b,c) \in R\) implies that \((a,c) \in R\).

item.title: Injectivity, surjectivity, and bijectivity
item.description: Definitions A function or map \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C}\) is called injective if and only if for all \(a,b \in \mathcal{D}\) such that \(a \neq b\), we have that \(f(a) \neq f(b)\). It is called surjective if and only if for all \(y \in \mathcal{C}\), there exists an \(x \in \mathcal{D}\) such that \(f(x) = y\). It is called bijective if and only if it is both injective and surjective.

item.title: Cardinality
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: Greatest Common Divisors
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: The dual map
item.description: Definition Let \(V\) and \(W\) be vector spaces and let \(T \in \Lin(V, W)\) be a linear map. Then the dual map \(T': W' \to V'\) is defined by \(T' (\varphi) = \varphi \circ T\) for \(\varphi \in W'\) where \(V'\) and \(W'\) are the dual spaces of \(V\) and \(W\). Properties The map \(T'\) is linear since it is the composition of a linear map and a linear functional.

item.title: Quotients of vector spaces
item.description: They are themselves also vector spaces. Definitions Let \(U\) be a subspace of a vector space \(V\). The quotient space \(V / U\) is the set of all affine subsets of \(V\) parallel to \(U\). That is, \[V / U = \{v + U \mid v \in V\}.\] For a subspace \(U\) of \(V\), the quotient map, denoted by \(\pi: V \to V / U\) is a linear map defined by \(\pi(v) = v + U\).

item.title: Systems of linear equations
item.description: Definitions A homogeneous system of linear equations is a system consisting of \(m\) linear equations in \(n\) variables for some positive integers \(m\) and \(n\) of the form \[\begin{align*} \sum_{k=1}^n A_{1,k} x_k &= 0 \\ &\vdots \\ \sum_{k=1}^n A_{m,k} x_k &= 0 \end{align*}\] where \(A_j,k \in \F\) for \(j=1, \dots m\) and \(k=1, \dots n\). An inhomogeneous system of linear equations is a system consisting of \(m\) linear equations in \(n\) variables for some positive integers \(m\) and \(n\) of the form \[\begin{align*} \sum_{k=1}^n A_{1,k} x_k &= c_1 \\ &\vdots \\ \sum_{k=1}^n A_{m,k} x_k &= c_m \end{align*}\] where \(A_{j,k}, c_j \in \F\) for \(j=1, \dots m\), \(k=1, \dots n\), and the \(c_j\) are not all zero.

item.title: Affine subsets
item.description: Definition An affine subset of a vector space \(V\) is a subset of the form \(v + U\) where \(v \in V\), \(U\) is a subspace of \(V\), and \[v + U = \{v + u \mid u \in U\}\] is the sum of the vector \(v\) and the space \(U\). For \(v \in V\) and \(U\) a subspace of \(V\), we say that the affine subset \(v + U\) is parallel to \(U\).

item.title: The dual basis
item.description: Definition Let \(V\) be a vector space with basis \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\). We define the dual basis to be the list \((\varphi_1, \dots, \varphi_n)\) of linear functionals on \(V\) such that \[\varphi_j(v_k) = \begin{cases} 1 & k=j \\ 0 & k \neq j \end{cases},\] that is, \(\varphi_j\) is the linear map from \(V\) to \(\F\) assigning \(1\) to the \(j\)th basis vector of \(V\) and \(0\) to all other basis vectors.

item.title: The dual space
item.description: Definitions Let \(V\) be a vector space over \(\F\). A linear functional on \(V\) is a linear map \(T \in \Lin(V, \F)\). We call \(V' = \Lin(V, \F)\) the dual space of \(V\), the vector space of all linear functionals on \(V\). Properties We have that \(\dim V' = \dim (\Lin (V, \F)) = (\dim V) (\dim \F) = \dim V\). Examples Let \(V = \Poly (\R)\). Then \(V'\) is the space of all linear maps from \(\Poly (\R)\) to \(\R\).

item.title: Direct sums of subspaces
item.description: Definition Let \(U_1, \dots, U_m\) be subspaces of a vector space \(V\). If each element \(u \in U_1 + \dots + U_m\) can be written uniquely as a sum \(u_1 + \dots + u_m\) where each \(u_i \in U_i\), then this sum is called a direct sum. In this case, we write the sum as \(U_1 \oplus \dots \oplus U_m\). Properties (1.44) Proposition: Let \(U_1, \dots, U_n\) be subspaces of a vector space \(V\).

item.title: Linear maps
item.description: Also called linear transformations. Definition A linear map from a vector space \(V\) to a vector space \(W\) is a function \(T: V \to W\) with the following properties: additivity: \(T(u + v) = T(u) + T(v)\) for all \(u,v \in V\); homogeneity: \(T(av) = aT(v)\) for all \(v \in V\) and \(a \in \F\). We denote the set of all linear maps from \(V\) to \(W\) by \(\Lin (V, W)\).

item.title: Operators
item.description: Definition Let \(V\) be a vector space. An operator on \(V\) is a linear map from \(V\) to itself. We denote the space of operators on \(V\) by \(\Lin (V)\) (shortening the notation from \(\Lin (V, V))\). Properties (3.69) Theorem: Let \(V\) be a finite-dimensional vector space. For an operator \(T \in \Lin(V)\), the following are equivalent: \(T\) is invertible; \(T\) is injective; \(T\) is surjective.

item.title: Products of vector spaces
item.description: Guess what? They are also vector spaces. Definition Let \(V_1, \dots, V_n\) be vector spaces over \(\F\). The product of these spaces, denoted \(V_1 \times \dots \times V_n\) is the set \[\{(v_1, \dots, v_n) \mid v_1 \in V_1, \dots, v_n \in V_n\}.\] (This is the same way we define finite cartesian products.) Properties We define addition and scalar multiplication on \(V_1 \times \dots \times V_n\) as follows: \[\begin{gather*} (a_1, \dots, a_n) + (b_1, \dots, b_n) = (a_1 + b_1, \dots, a_n + b_n); \\ c (a_1, \dots, a_n) = (ca_1, \dots, ca_n).

item.title: Invertibility of linear maps
item.description: Definitions Let \(V\) and \(W\) be vector spaces. A linear map \(T \in \Lin (V, W)\) is called invertible if there exists a map \(S \in \Lin(W, V)\) such that the products \(ST\) and \(TS\) are the identity maps on \(V\) and \(W\), respectively. We call the map \(S\) the inverse of \(T\), denoted \(T\inv\) (see the uniqueness property below). An invertible linear map \(T \in \Lin(V, W)\) is called an isomorphism, and the spaces \(V\) and \(W\) are called isomorphic to one another.

item.title: Basis of a vector space
item.description: Definition Let \(V\) be a vector space. A basis of \(V\) is a list of vectors in \(V\) that is linearly independent and spans \(V\). Properties (2.29) Proposition: A list \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) is a basis of \(V\) if and only if every \(v \in V\) can be uniquely expressed as a linear combination of \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\). (2.31) Theorem: Every spanning list \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) of \(V\) can be reduced to a basis by removing some of the \(v_i\) from the list.

item.title: Dimension of a vector space
item.description: Definition The dimension of a finite dimensional vector space \(V\), denoted \(\dim V\), is the length of any basis of \(V\). Properties (2.43) Theorem: If \(U_1\) and \(U_2\) are subspaces of a vector space \(V\), then their sum satisfies \[\dim (U_1 + U_2) = \dim U_1 + \dim U_2 - \dim (U_1 \cap U_2).\] (3.22) Fundamental Theorem of Linear Maps: If \(V\) is a finite-dimensional vector space and \(T \in \Lin(V,W)\) is a linear map, then \[\dim V = \dim \, \nl T + \dim \, \range T,\] where \(\nl T\) and \(\range T\) denote the null space and range of \(T\), respectively.

item.title: Linear (in)dependence
item.description: Definitions A list of vectors \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) in a vector space \(V\) is linearly independent if and only if \(a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0\) implies that \(a_1 = \dots = a_n = 0\). The list is linearly dependent if and only if it is not linearly independent. Note: These definitions follow Sheldon Axler’s book Linear Algebra Done Right, in which linear (in)dependence is defined in terms of lists of vectors, and not sets of vectors.

item.title: Null spaces
item.description:
Also known as kernels… Definition Let \(T \in \Lin(V,W)\) be a linear map between vector spaces \(V\) and \(W\). The null space of \(T\), denoted \(
l T\), is the subset of \(V\) containing vectors that \(T\) maps to the zero vector in \(W\), that is, \[
l T = \{v \in V \mid Tv = 0\}.\] Properties (3.14) Proposition: If \(T \in \Lin(V,W)\), then \(
l T\) is a subspace of \(V\).

item.title: Products of linear maps
item.description: Definition Let \(U\), \(V\), and \(W\) be vector spaces. If \(T \in \Lin(U, V)\) and \(S \in \Lin(V, W)\) are linear maps such that \(T\) maps \(U\) into the domain of \(S\), then we define the product \(ST \in \Lin(U, W)\) by \((ST)v = S(Tv)\), that is, \(ST\) is the composition \(S \circ T\) of the two maps. Properties Associativity. If \(T_1\), \(T_2\), and \(T_3\) are linear maps such that \(T_3\) maps into the domain of \(T_2\) which in turn maps into the domain of \(T_1\), then \((T_1 T_2) T_3 = T_1 (T_2 T_3)\).

item.title: Subspaces of a vector space
item.description: Definition Let \(V\) be a vector space. A subset \(U\) of \(V\) is a subspace of \(V\) if and only if it is also a vector space. Properties Since many properties of the vector space \(V\) are inherited, a subset \(U\) is a subspace provided it satisfies the following: additive identity: \(0 \in U\); closed under addition: \(u,v \in U\) implies \(u + v \in U\); closed under scalar multiplication: \(a \in \F\), \(v \in V\) implies \(av \in U\).

item.title: Sums of subspaces
item.description: Definition Let \(U_1, \dots, U_m\) be subspaces of a vector space \(V\). The sum of \(U_1, \dots, U_m\) is \[U_1 + \dots + U_m = \{u_1 + \dots + u_m \mid u_1 \in U_1, \dots, u_m \in U_m\},\] the set of all possible sums of elements of the \(U_i\). Properties The sum of subspaces \(U_1 + \dots + U_m\) is a subspace. \(0 \in U_i\) for all \(i = 1, \dots, m\), so \(0 = \overbrace{0 + \dots + 0}^{m \text{ times}} \in U_1 + \dots + U_m\).

item.title: Differentiation and derivatives
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: Integration and integrals
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: Arithmetic progression topology
item.description: Definition The arithmetic progression topology is a topology on \(\mathbb{Z}\) generated by the basis of sets of arithmetic progressions (sets of the form \(\{az + b \mid z \in \mathbb{Z}\}\) for \(a,b \in \mathbb{Z}\), \(a \neq 0\)) and is denoted \(\mathbb{Z}_\text{arith}\).

item.title: Complex numbers
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: K-topology
item.description: Denoted \(\Rh\) in the textbook I’ve been using, the K-topology is a topology on \(\mathbb{R}\). Definition Let \(K = \{1/n\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}\) be the harmonic sequence. The K-topology on \(\mathbb{R}\) is generated by the basis containing sets of the form \((a,b)\) and sets of the form \((a,b) - K\) where \(a, b \in \mathbb{R}\) with \(a < b\). Properties \(\Rh\) is finer than the standard topology. Separation properties \(T_1\)-space Hausdorff Not regular or \(T_3\) (can’t separate \(0\) and \(K\)) Not normal or \(T_4\)

item.title: Linear combinations
item.description: Definition Let \(V\) be a vector space over \(\F\) and let \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) be a list of vectors in \(V\). A linear combination of this list is a vector of the form \[a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n\] where \(a_1, \dots, a_n \in \F\). Examples The vector \((7,2,9) \in \R^3\) is a linear combination of the vectors \((2,1,3)\) and \((1,0,1)\) since \[(7,2,9) = 2(2,1,3) + 3(1,0,1)\]

item.title: Lists
item.description: Definition Let \(n\) be a nonnegative integer. Then a list of length \(n\) is an ordered collection of \(n\) objects, \((x_1, \dots, x_n)\). For \(j \in \{1, \dots, n\}\), we call the element \(x_j\) the \(j\)th coordinate of the list. Properties Two lists are equal if and only if they have the same length and the same coordinates in the same order. That is \((x_1, \dots, x_n) = (y_1, \dots, y_m)\) if and only if \(n = m\) and \(x_j = y_j\) for all \(j = 1, \dots, n\).

item.title: Order topology
item.description: Definition Let \(X\) be a set totally ordered by a relation \(\leq\). The order topology on \(X\) is the topology generated by the basis \(\B\) where \(\B\) is the collection of subsets of \(X\) of the form \(\{x \in X \mid x < a\}\), \(\{x \in X \mid a < x\}\), or \(\{x \in X \mid a < x < b\}\) for \(a, b \in X\). Properties If \(X\) is a set totally ordered by a relation \(\leq\), then the order topology on \(X\) has a subbasis \(\Sub\) containing sets of the form \(\{x \in X \mid x < a\}\) or \(\{x \in X \mid a < x\}\).

item.title: Sequences
item.description: They’re like lists but they’re infinitely long. Definitions For real numbers, a sequence is a function \(f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}\), where the image of the number \(n\) under \(f\) is typically called \(a_n\). The sequence is written by listing its images: \(a_1, a_2, \dots\) or for short, \(\{a_n\}\). In a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), a sequence is a function \(f: \mathbb{N} \to X\), where the image of the number \(i\) under \(f\) is typically called \(x_i\).

item.title: Span
item.description: Definition Let \(v_1, \dots, v_n \in V\) be vectors in a vector space over \(\F\). The span of the list \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\), denoted \(\Span(v_1, \dots, v_n)\), is the set of all linear combinations, that is \[\Span(v_1, \dots, v_n) = \{a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n \mid a_1, \dots, a_n \in \F \}.\] Properties For a list of vectors \((v_1, \dots, v_n)\) in \(V\), \(\Span(v_1, \dots, v_n)\) is a subspace of \(V\).

item.title: Subbasis for a topological space
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space and let \(\Sub \subset \T\). \(\Sub\) is a subbasis for the topology \(\T\) if and only if the collection \(\B\) of all finite intersections of sets in \(\Sub\) is a basis for \(\T\). If \(\Sub\) is a subbasis, we call \(S \in \Sub\) a subbasic open set. Properties Exercise 3.13: If \(\B\) is a basis for a topology \(\T\), then it is also a subbasis.

item.title: Subspaces in topology
item.description: Much like in other areas, a subspace is a subset that still has extra structure. Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space and let \(Y\) be a subset of \(X\). The collection \[\T_Y = \{ U \mid U = V \cap Y \text{ for some } V \in \T \}\] is a topology on \(Y\) called the subspace topology or the relative topology on \(Y\) inherited from \(X\). The space \((Y, \T_Y)\) is called a (topological) subspace of \((X, \T)\).

item.title: The Double Headed Snake
item.description: The body is the positive real line and the two heads are the points \(0'\) and \(0''\). Definition The Double Headed Snake is the topological space on the set \(\R_{+00}\) of all positive real numbers together with the numbers \(0'\) and \(0''\) that is generated by the basis \(\B\) containing sets of the form \((a,b)\), \((0,b) \cup \{0'\}\), and \((0,b) \cup \{0''\}\) where \(a,b \in \mathbb{R}\). Properties Separation properties \(T_1\)-space Not Hausdorff (can’t separate \(0'\) and \(0''\)) Not regular or a \(T_3\)-space Not normal or a \(T_4\)-space

item.title: The Moore plane
item.description: Also called the Upper Half-Plane with the Sticky Bubble Topology and denoted \(\Hbub\) in the textbook I’ve been using. Definition Let \(\mathbb{H} = \{(x,y) \mid x,y \in \mathbb{R}, y \geq 0\}\). The Moore plane is this set with the topology generated by the basis containing - all balls of the form \(B((x,y), r)\) where \(0<r \leq y\), and - all balls of the form \(B((x,y),r) \cup \{(x,0)\}\) where \(r = y > 0\).

item.title: The product topology
item.description: Definitely review the page on infinite cartesian products for this one. Definition Let \(\{(X_\alpha, \T_\alpha)\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) be a collection of topological spaces. We can define a topology on the product \(\prod_{\alpha \in \lambda} X_\alpha\) generated by the subbasis consisting of sets of the form \(\pi_\beta\inv (U_\beta)\) where \(\pi_\beta\) is a projection function, \(\beta \in \lambda\), and \(U_\beta\) is open in the space \((X_\beta, \T_\beta)\). We call this topology the product topology.

item.title: The Sorgenfrey line
item.description: It’s like \(\R\) but finer and… worse. It’s a topological space also known as the lower limit topology on \(\R\), sometimes denoted \(\RLL\) or \(\mathbb{R}_{\text{bad}}^1\). Definition The Sorgenfrey Line is the topological space on \(\mathbb{R}\) generated by the basis of sets of the form \([a, b) = \{x \in \mathbb{R} \mid a \leq x < b\}\) for \(a, b \in \mathbb{R}\). Properties Separation properties \(T_1\)-space Hausdorff Regular and a \(T_3\)-space Normal and a \(T_4\)-space

item.title: The standard topology
item.description: The standard topology is a topology defined on \(\mathbb{R}^n\) for \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). Definitions The Euclidean distance between two points \(x = (x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n)\) and \(y = (y_1, y_2, \dots, y_n)\) is defined as \[d(x,y) = \left( \sum_{i = 1}^n (x_i - y_i)^2 \right)^{\frac{1}{2}}.\] An open ball of radius \(\varepsilon > 0\) around a point \(p \in \mathbb{R}^n\) is the set \(B(p, \varepsilon) = \{x \mid d(p,x) < \varepsilon\}\).

item.title: The topologist's sine curve
item.description: A set in the standard topology on \(\mathbb{R}^2\). Definition In \((\mathbb{R}^2, \mathcal{T}_\text{std})\), the topologist’s sine curve is the set \[S = \left\{ \left( x, \sin \left(\frac{1}{x}\right) \right) \, \bigg \vert \, x \in (0,1) \right\}.\] Properties Every point in the set \(\{(0,y) \mid -1 \leq y \leq 1 \}\) is a limit point of the topologist’s sine curve. Since none of the above points are in \(S\), \(S\) is not closed.

item.title: What does it mean to be a topology?
item.description: A topology on a set is a way of determining which subsets are open, closed, neither, or both. Elements of open sets can be thought of as being “close” in a way that isn’t dependent on notions of distance. If \(X\) is a set and \(\mathcal{T}\) is a topology on \(X\), then we call \((X, \mathcal{T})\) a topological space. Definition Let \(X\) be a set. Then \(\mathcal{T}\) is a topology on \(X\) if and only if \(\mathcal{T}\) is a collection of subsets of \(X\) such that:

item.title: $T_4$ spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is \(T_4\) if and only if it is both \(T_1\) and normal. Properties Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_4\), it is also normal, \(T_3\), regular, Hausdorff, and \(T_1\).

item.title: $T_5$ spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is \(T_5\) if and only if it is both \(T_1\) and completely normal. Properties Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_5\), it is also completely normal by definition, normal since disjoint closed sets are separated, \(T_3\), regular, Hausdorff, and \(T_1\).

item.title: Completely normal spaces
item.description: Definitions Two sets \(A\) and \(B\) in a topological space are separated if and only if \(\overline{A} \cap B = \emptyset\) and \(A \cap \overline{B} = \emptyset\). A topological space \((X, \T)\) is completely normal if and only if for any two separated sets \(A\) and \(B\), there exist open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(A \subset U\) and \(B \subset A\). Properties Theorem 4.26: A topological space \((X, \T)\) is completely normal if and only if it is hereditarily normal.

item.title: Heredity
item.description: What properties do subspaces inherit? Definition Let \(P\) be a property of a topological space \((X, \T)\). Then the space is hereditarily \(P\) if and only if every subspace \(Y \subset X\) with the relative topology \(\T_Y\) also has the property \(P\). Properties Theorem 4.26: A topological space \((X, \T)\) is hereditarily normal if and only if it is completely normal. Examples Theorem 4.19: Hausdorff spaces are hereditarily Hausdorff. Theorem 4.

item.title: Fineness and Coarseness
item.description: Given two topologies on a set \(X\), we can compare them with the notions of fineness and coarseness. You can think about the fineness of a topology determining the amount you can see (you “see” the open sets) when looking at the set \(X\). If a topology is very fine, you can see a lot of open sets, but if the topology is very coarse, things are “blurry” because there are few open sets.

item.title: Infimum and supremum
item.description: Definitions Let \(A \subset \mathbb{R}\). We say \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is an upper bound of \(A\) if and only if \(c \geq a\) for all \(a \in A\). We say \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is a lower bound of \(A\) if and only if \(c \leq a\) for all \(a \in A\). We say \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) is the greatest/largest/maximum element of \(A\) if and only if \(c\) is an upper bound of \(A\) and \(c \in A\).

item.title: Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)
item.description: Theorem statement Let \(f: [a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) be continuous and let \(L \in \mathbb{R}\) be a number strictly between \(f(a)\) and \(f(b)\). Then there exists a \(c \in (a,b)\) such that \(f(c) = L\). Lemma Let \(a, L \in \mathbb{R}\) and let \(f\) be a function that is continuous at \(a\) with \(f(a) < L\) (\(f(a) > L\)). Then there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(\vert x - a \vert < \delta\) implies that \(f(x) < L\) (\(f(x) > L\)).

item.title: My Topology self-study work
item.description: I’ve been using the book Topology Through Inquiry and proofs and exercises I’ve done from the book can be found here.

item.title: Open sets
item.description: Definition In a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), an open set \(U\) is a set with \(U \in \mathcal{T}\). Properties of open sets Theorem 2.3: A set \(U\) is open if and only if for each point \(p \in U\), there exists an open set \(U_p\) such that \(p \in U_p \subset U\). If \(\{U_\alpha\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) is a collection of open sets, then \(\bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha\) is open, but \(\bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha\) need not be open.

item.title: Power sets
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: Real number exponents
item.description: If \(a>0\) and \(r\) are real numbers, does \(a^r\) make sense? We need to extend exponentiation beyond repeated multiplication… \(n\)th roots Let \(n \in \N\) be a natural number and let \(a > 0\). Then we define the \(n\)th root of \(a\), written \(a^{\frac{1}{n}}\) or \(\sqrt[n]{a}\) to be the unique positive real number whose \(n\)th power is \(a\). Proposition: Such a number \(\sqrt[n]{a}\) exists for all \(a>0\) and \(n \in \N\).

item.title: The boundedness theorem
item.description: Theorem statement If \(f: [a,b] \to \R\) is a continuous function, then \(f\) is bounded. Lemmata Lemma 1: If \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \R\) is continuous at \(a \in \mathcal{D}\), then there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(f\) is bounded on \((a - \delta, a + \delta)\). Proof 1: Let \(\varepsilon = 1\). By the continuity of \(f\) at \(a\), choose \(\delta > 0\) such that \(\vert x - a \vert < \delta\) implies \(\vert f(x) - f(a) \vert < \varepsilon = 1\).

item.title: The Extreme Value Theorem (EVT)
item.description: Theorem statement If \(f: [a,b] \to \R\) be a continuous function, then there exist \(c,d \in [a,b]\) such that \(f(c) \leq f(x) \leq f(d)\) for all \(x \in [a,b]\). Proof Suppose \(f: [a,b] \to \R\) be a continuous function. Then by the boundedness theorem, the set \(A = \{f(x) \mid x \in [a,b]\}\) is bounded and nonempty. By the completeness axiom, the set \(A\) has a supremum, say \(\sup A = M\).

item.title: Basis for a topological space
item.description: Similar to the ideas behind bases in other areas of math. Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space and let \(\B \subset \T\). \(\B\) is a basis for the topology \(\T\) if and only if every open set is the union of elements of \(\B\). If \(\mathcal{B}\) is a basis, we call \(B \in \B\) a basic open set. Properties Theorem 3.1: A set \(\mathcal{B}\) is the basis for a given topology \(\mathcal{T}\) on a set \(X\) if and only if

item.title: Basis for a topological space
item.description: Similar to the ideas behind bases in other areas of math. Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space and let \(\B \subset \T\). \(\B\) is a basis for the topology \(\T\) if and only if every open set is the union of elements of \(\B\). If \(\mathcal{B}\) is a basis, we call \(B \in \B\) a basic open set. Properties Theorem 3.1: A set \(\mathcal{B}\) is the basis for a given topology \(\mathcal{T}\) on a set \(X\) if and only if

item.title: Closures
item.description: Taking a set and adding a few points to make it closed. Definition Let \((X, \mathcal{T})\) be a topological space with \(A \subset X\). The closure of \(A\) in \(X\), denoted \(\overline{A}\), Cl\((A)\), or Cl\(_X(A)\) is the set \(A\) together with all its limit points in \(X\). Properties Theorem 2.13: The closure of a set is closed, that is, for a set \(A\) in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), we have that \(\overline{\overline{A}} = \overline{A}\).

item.title: The lexicographically ordered square
item.description: Sets have interesting closures. Definition The unit square \([0,1] \times [0,1]\) is totally ordered by the lexicographic order, and the lexicographically ordered square is the topological space formed from the unit square together with the associated order topology. Properties Many sets have very interesting, unexpected closures. See Exercise 3.21. Separation Properties \(T_1\)-space Hausdorff Regular and a \(T_3\)-space Normal and a \(T_4\)-space These follow from the fact that this is a space with an order topology.

item.title: $T_1$ spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is a \(T_1\)-space if and only if for every pair of distinct points \(x\) and \(y\), there exist open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(x \in U\) and \(y \in V\) but \(x \notin V\) and \(y \notin U\). Properties Theorem 4.1: A space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_1\) if and only if singletons are closed. Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is Hausdorff, \(T_3\), or \(T_4\), it is also \(T_1\).

item.title: $T_3$ spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is \(T_3\) if and only if it is both \(T_1\) and regular. Properties Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_4\), it is also \(T_3\), and therefore also regular, Hausdorff, and \(T_1\).

item.title: Countable complement topology
item.description: Basically what the name makes it sound like. It’s similar in definition to the finite complement topology. Definition Let \(X\) be a set. A set \(U\) is in the countable complement topology if and only if \(X - U\) is countable or if \(U = \emptyset\). This topology is also called the cocountable topology. Properties Countable sets are closed in this topology. For a countable set, the countable complement topology is just the discrete_topology.

item.title: Finite complement topology
item.description: Basically what the name makes it sound like. Similar in definition to the countable complement topology. Definition Let \(X\) be a set. A set \(U\) is in the finite complement topology if and only if \(X - U\) is finite or if \(U = \emptyset\). This topology is also called the cofinite topology. Properties Finite sets are closed in the finite complement topology. For a finite set, the finite complement topology is just the discrete topology.

item.title: Hausdorff spaces
item.description: Also called \(T_2\)-spaces. Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is Hausdorff if and only if for every pair of distinct points \(x\) and \(y\), there exist disjoint open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(x \in U\) and \(y \in V\). Properties Theorem 4.7: If a space \((X, \T)\) is \(T_3\), or \(T_4\), it is also Hausdorff and therefore also \(T_1\).

item.title: Indiscrete topology
item.description: The coarsest possible topology on a set \(X\). Definition Let \(X\) be a set. The indiscrete topology is \(\mathcal{T} = \{\emptyset, X\}\). The topological space \((X, \{\emptyset, X\})\) is called an indiscrete space. Properties By definition, the only sets in the indiscrete topology that are open are \(X\) and \(\emptyset\), and these are also the only closed sets. Separation Properties Not a \(T_1\)-space Not Hausdorff Not regular or a \(T_3\)-space Not normal or a \(T_4\)-space

item.title: Normal spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is normal if and only if for every pair of disjoint, closed sets \(A\) and \(B\), there are disjoint open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(A \subset U\) and \(B \subset V\). Properties Theorem 4.9: A space \((X, \T)\) is normal if and only if for every closed set \(A \subset X\) and open set \(U\) containing \(A\), there exists an open set \(V\) such that \(A \subset V\) and \(\overline{V} \subset U\).

item.title: Regular spaces
item.description: Definition Let \((X, \T)\) be a topological space. It is regular if and only if for every point \(x \in X\) and closed set \(A \subset X\) with \(x \notin A\), there exist disjoint open sets \(U\) and \(V\) such that \(x \in U\) and \(A \subset V\). Properties Theorem 4.8: A space \((X, \T)\) is regular if and only if for each point \(p \in X\) and open set \(U\) with \(p \in U\), there exists an open set \(V\) such that \(p \in V\) and \(\overline{V} \subset U\) (where \(\overline{V}\) is the closure of \(V\) in \((X, \T)\)).

item.title: The discrete topology
item.description: The discrete topology is the finest topology on a given set. A set together with the discrete topology is called a discrete space. Definition Let \(X\) be a set. Then the discrete topology on \(X\) contains all subsets of \(X\), that is, the topology is \(\mathcal{T} = 2^X\), the power set of \(X\). Properties If \((X, \mathcal{T})\) is a topological space, then it is a discrete space if and only if all singletons are open.

item.title: Cardinality and sizes of infinity
item.description: Content coming soon.

item.title: Cartesian products
item.description: Definitions (two sets) Let \(A\) and \(B\) be sets. Their Cartesian product, \(A \times B\), is the set \(\{(a,b) \mid a \in A, b \in B\}\). An element \((a,b)\) of \(A \times B\) can be projected back to the set \(A\) or \(B\) with the projection functions \(\pi_X : X \times Y \to X\) and \(\pi_Y : X \times Y \to Y\) defined as \(\pi_X (a,b) = a\) and \(\pi_Y (a,b) = b\).

item.title: The box topology
item.description: Another, weirder topology on an infinite product. Definition Let \(\{(X_\alpha, \T_\alpha)\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) be a (possibly infinite) collection of topological spaces. The box topology on the product \(\prod_{\alpha \in \lambda} X_\alpha\) is the topology generated by a basis consisting of sets of the form \(\prod_{\alpha \in \lambda} U_\alpha\) where \(U_\alpha\) is open in \((X_\alpha, \T_\alpha)\) for each \(\alpha\). Properties As a consequence of Theorem 3.27, if the collection \(\{(X_\alpha, \T_\alpha)\}_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) is finite, the box topology on \(\prod_{\alpha \in \lambda} X_\alpha\) is the same as the product topology.

item.title: Thomae's function

item.title: Boundaries of sets
item.description: Definition For a set \(A\) in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), the boundary of \(A\), denoted \(\partial A\) or Bd\((A)\), is the intersection of the closures of \(A\) and its complement, that is, the set \(\partial A = \overline{X} \cap \overline{X - A}\). Properties Theorem 2.28: If \(A\) is a set in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), the interior of \(A\), the boundary of \(A\), and the interior of the complement of \(A\) are disjoint sets whose union is \(X\).

item.title: Continuity
item.description: Continuous functions can be drawn without picking up your pencil. The \(\varepsilon\)-\(\delta\), limit related definition A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) is continuous at a point \(c \in \mathcal{D}\) if and only if the limit of \(f\) at \(c\) exists and \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)\). A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) is continuous if and only if it is continuous at the point \(c\) for all \(c \in \mathcal{D}\).

item.title: DeMorgan's Laws
item.description: DeMorgan’s Laws relate complements of unions and intersections. Statement Let \(X\) be a set and let \(\lbrace A_\alpha \rbrace_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) be a collection of subsets of \(X\). Then \[X - \left( \bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha \right) = \bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} (X - A_\alpha)\] and \[X - \left( \bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha \right) = \bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} (X - A_\alpha).\] Proof The proof here is for a weaker version of the laws for a finite collection of sets, written as an exercise for my topology work.

item.title: Interior of a set
item.description: Points in the set and not on the boundary. Definition Let \((X, \mathcal{T})\) be a topological space and let \(A\) be a subset of \(X\). The interior of \(A\), denoted \(A^\circ\) or Int\((A)\), is the largest open set contained entirely within \(A\), that is, the set \[A^\circ = \bigcup_{U \subset A, \, U \in \mathcal{T}} U.\] Properties Theorem 2.26: A point \(p\) is an interior point of a set \(A\) in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\) if and only if there exists an open set \(U\) with \(p \in U \subset A\).

item.title: Limits
item.description: Intuitively, “\(\lim \limits_{x \to a} f(x) = L\)” means that the outputs of a function \(f\) approaches the value \(L\) as the inputs approach the value \(a\). The \(\varepsilon\)-\(\delta\) definition of a limit (and variants) Let \(f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a function and let \(a,L \in \mathbb{R}\). \(\lim \limits_{x \to a} f(x) = L\) if and only if for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists a \(\delta > 0\) such that \(0 < \vert x - a \vert < \delta\) implies that \(\vert f(x) - L \vert < \varepsilon\).

item.title: Closed sets
item.description: Definition In a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), a closed set \(A\) is a subset of \(X\) that is equal to its closure (\(\overline{A} = A\)). That is, \(A\) contains all its limit points. Properties of closed sets Theorem 2.14: A set \(A\) is closed if and only if its complement \(X - A\) is open. If \(\lbrace A_\alpha \rbrace_{\alpha \in \lambda}\) is a collection of closed sets, then \(\bigcap_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha\) is closed, but \(\bigcup_{\alpha \in \lambda} A_\alpha\) need not be closed.

item.title: Discontinuities
item.description: Definition A function \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) is discontinuous at a point \(c \in \mathcal{D}\) if and only if \(f\) is not continuous at \(c\). That is, if the limit \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x)\) does not exist or is not equal to \(f(c)\). Types of discontinuities Let \(f: \mathcal{D} \to \mathbb{R}\) be a function and \(c \in \mathcal{D}\). Then \(f\) has an infinite discontinuity at \(c\) if and only if \(\lim \limits_{x \to c} f(x) = \pm \infty\).

item.title: Isolated points
item.description: Definition Let \((X,\mathcal{T})\) be a topological space, \(A\) a subset of \(X\), and \(p \in A\) a point. We say \(p\) is an isolated point if it is not a limit point of \(A\). Properties If \(p\) is an isolated point of a set \(A\) in a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\), then there exists an open set \(U\) such that \(U \cap A = \{p\}\). Examples In the topological space defined by \(X = \{a,b,c,d\}\) and \(\mathcal{T} = \{\emptyset, X, \{a\},\{a,b\}\}\), the point \(b\) is in the set \(A = \{b,c\}\), but is not a limit point of \(A\) since \(\{a,b\}\) is open but \((\{a,b\} - \{b\}) \cap A = \emptyset\).

item.title: Limit points
item.description: Generalizing more things from calculus – this time the idea of a point being “arbitrarily close” to a set. Definition Let \((X, \mathcal{T})\) be a topological space, let \(A \subset X\) be a subset, and let \(p \in X\) be a point. We say that \(p\) is a limit point of \(A\) if and only if for each open set \(U\) containing \(p\), \((U - \{p\}) \cap A \neq \emptyset\).
